title: pr.probability - A new notion of probability coupling
body:
Let $X$ and $Y$ be two discrete random variables distributed according to $\mu$ and $
u$ , respectively. Consider the following optimization problems $$\inf_{\pi\in \Pi(\mu, 
u)}\Pr(X
eq Y),$$ where $\Pi(\mu, 
u)$ denotes the set of all couplings of $\mu$ and $
u$ , i.e., all joint distributions $P_{XY}$ whose marginals are given by $\mu$ and $
u$ . It is very well-known that the above minimization is given by total variation distance: $$\inf_{\pi\in \Pi(\mu, 
u)}\Pr(X
eq Y) = d_{TV}(\mu, 
u).$$ My question is s follows. Now consider $X\sim \mu$ and $Y_1$ and $Y_2$ are two independent samples of $
u$ . Now, what is $$\inf_{\pi\in \Pi(\mu, 
u)}\Pr(X
eq Y_1, X
eq Y_2)?$$ Has it appeared before? u$ and $\pi$ is the diagonal coupling, and both $(X,Y_1)$ and $(X,Y_2)$ are assumed to be distributed according to $\pi$, then we have $X=Y_1$ a.s. and $X=Y_2$ a.s., so it is problematic to require that $Y_1$ and $Y_2$ are independent.) $\endgroup$ Mateusz Kwaśnicki –  Mateusz Kwaśnicki 2020-07-31 01:06:04 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 1:06 $ egingroup$ Yes, I mean $\pi(X

u(y_1)
u(y_2)P_{X|Y_1Y_2}(x|y_1,y_2)$ for some conditional distribution $P_{X|Y_1Y_2}$. Then the first marginal should be $\mu$, the second and third should be $
u$. $\endgroup$ math-Student –  math-Student 2020-07-31 01:43:10 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 1:43 $ egingroup$ If $\mu =

u$, while under the infimum a triple coupling $ ar\pi$ of $\mu$, $
u$ and $
u$ is used. My point is that for a general $\pi$ it is not possible to construct any $ ar\pi$ such that $\pi(A 	imes B) =  ar\pi(A 	imes B 	imes \mathcal Y) =  ar\pi(A 	imes \mathcal Y 	imes B)$ and $ ar\pi(\mathcal X 	imes B_1 	imes B_2) = 
u(B_1)
u(B_2)$. (Here of course $\mathcal X$ is the set of all possible outcomes of $X$, and $\mathcal Y$ the set of all outcomes of $Y$.) $\endgroup$ Mateusz Kwaśnicki –  Mateusz Kwaśnicki 2020-07-31 08:49:40 +00:00 Commented Jul 31, 2020 at 8:49 1 $ egingroup$ Note that this quantity can vanish even if $\mu
